= Example Commands =

== Cloning specific branch ==
{{{bash 
git clone --single-branch --branch <BRANCH_NAME> <remote-repo>
}}}

= Errors =  

== failed to push some refs to <REPO> ==
`git push -u origin <BRANCH_NAME> --force`


= Dotfile Management =

Run the following commands:
{{{bash

git init --bare ~/.dotfiles
alias config='/usr/bin/git --git-dir=$HOME/.dotfiles --work-tree=$HOME'
echo "/usr/bin/git --git-dir=$HOME/.dotfiles --work-tree=$HOME" >> ~/.config/shell/alias

}}}

From then on, you can add files to the directory by running the following commands:
{{{bash

config add .zshenv
config commit -m "Message"
***REMOVED*** Create a new repository on github or gitlab
config remote add origin git@github.com:<USERNAME>/<REPONAME>.git
config push --set-upstream origin <BRANCH_NAME>

}}}


== Setting Up ==

{{{bash
ssh-keygen -t rsa -C "you@example.com"
}}}
* Go to [[github account settings|https://github.com/settings/profile]]
* Click "SSH-Keys" on the left
* Click "Add SSH Key"
* Add a label and follow instructions
* Then, execute teh following
{{{bash
ssh -T git@github.com
}}}

== Errors ==

=== publickey permission denied ===
[[https://docs.github.com/en/authentication/troubleshooting-ssh/error-permission-denied-publickey|Article that explains more]]
{{{bash

git@github.com: Permission denied (publickey).
    fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

    Please make sure you have the correct access rights
    and the repository exists.
    
}}}

===== Solution =====
{{{

eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
ssh-add -l -E md5

}}}
Might give the below error.


=== The Agent Has No Identities ===
You might need to regenerate an sshkey

`ssh-keygen -t rsa`
`ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_rsa`
`ssh-add -l -E md5`

Afterwards, simply add the ssh key to github (check the contents of ~/.ssh/id_rsa)
